text: Lament for the Leaders of Israel
“And you, raise a lament about\f + \fr 19:1 \ft Or “over” \f* the leaders of Israel,
and you must say,
‘What a lioness \add was\add* your mother
among \add the\add* lions.
She lay down in the midst of young lions,
\add and\add* she reared her lion cubs.
And she raised up one from her cubs;
he became a fierce lion,
and he learned to tear prey;
he ate\f + \fr 19:3 \ft Or “devoured” \f* humans.\f + \fr 19:3 \ft Hebrew “human” \f*
And nations heard about him;
in their pit he was caught,
and they brought him with hooks
to the land of Egypt.
And she saw\f + \fr 19:5 \ft Or “realized” \f* that she was waiting \add in vain\add*;
her hope was destroyed,
and she took one from her cubs,
\add and\add* she made him a fierce lion.
And he walked about in the midst of lions;
he became a fierce lion,
and he learned to tear prey;
he ate\f + \fr 19:6 \ft Or “devoured” \f* humans.\f + \fr 19:6 \ft Hebrew “human” \f*
And he knew their widows,\f + \fr 19:7 \ft Or “ravished/raped”; or “he ravaged their strongholds” \f*
and he devastated their cities,
and \add the\add* land was appalled, and ⸤everyone in it⸥\f + \fr 19:7 \ft Literally “its fullness” \f*
at the sound of his roar.
And nations set out against him
⸤from the surrounding provinces⸥,\f + \fr 19:8 \ft Literally “all around from \fq the \ft provinces” \f*
and they spread their net over him,
and he was caught in their pit.
And they put him in a collar with hooks,
and they brought him to the king of Babylon;
they brought him into\f + \fr 19:9 \ft Hebrew “in” \f* a prison,
so that his voice \add would\add* not be heard ⸤any longer⸥\f + \fr 19:9 \ft Literally “longer” \f*
on the mountains of Israel.
Your mother \add was\add* like the vine in your vineyard;\f + \fr 19:10 \ft Or “in the vineyard” \f*
planted ⸤fruitfully⸥\f + \fr 19:10 \ft Literally “fruitful” \f* beside water,
and it was full of branches
from many waters.\f + \fr 19:10 \ft Or “from waters abundant/many” \f*
And ⸤she produced branches of strength⸥\f + \fr 19:11 \ft Literally “they became to her branches/rods of strength” \f*
to\f + \fr 19:11 \ft Or “for” \f* scepters of rulers;
its height became tall
between\f + \fr 19:11 \ft Or “among” \f* thick foliage,
and it was seen\f + \fr 19:11 \ft Or “visible” \f* because of its tallness
among the abundance of its branches.
But it was uprooted in rage;
it was thrown to the earth,
and the east wind dried up its fruit;
they were stripped off,
and its strong branch dried up;
fire consumed it.
And now \add it is\add* planted in the desert,
in a ⸤dry and thirsty land⸥.\f + \fr 19:13 \ft Literally “a land of dryness and thirst” \f*
And \add so\add* fire has gone out from the stem of its branches;
its fruit it has consumed,
and \add there\add* was not in it ⸤a strong branch⸥,\f + \fr 19:14 \ft Literally “a branch of strength” \f*
a scepter for ruling.’ ”
This \add is\add* a lament, and ⸤it will be used as a lament⸥.\f + \fr 19:14 \ft Literally “she \fq is \ft for a lament” \f*
